semType.name: Pragmatic_function
semType.definition: Semantic types that inherit from this abstract type are used to mark lexical units that have some notable pragmatic dimension to their meaning, e.g., Positive_judgement for a word like "thrifty" (see Frugality.thrifty.a) and Question_function for a word like "who" (see Person.who.n).

semType.name: Body_of_water
semType.definition: Labels LU's which designate bodies of water. The limits of a body of water are defined in terms of the land that borders the water. Equivlent to WN Body of water. (Appropriate for LU's in Locale frame and its descendants.)

semType.name: Running-water
semType.definition: Labels LU's that designate geographical features of running water. Equivalent to WN watercourse. (Appropriate for LU's in Locale and descendants of Locale.)

semType.name: Sentient
semType.definition: Marks FEs whose fillers are sentient beings; dogs, definitely; bacteria, probably not; comatose people, planeria, maybe. This is a common-sense type, with fuzzy boundaries, not a precise bio-medical category.

semType.name: Landform
semType.definition: Labels LU's which designate land geography/topography. Such LU's give some information about the 3-D shape of the land. (Appropriate for LU's in Locale frame and its descendants.)

semType.name: Activity
semType.definition: Labels Activity Aktionsart. Used for events that fundamentally denote the 'Ongoing' subpart of an X-schema. E.g. We walked _for an hour_. Note that most verbs which inherently denote an Activity can be used as Accomplishments when a distinct goal is mentioned: We walked to the

semType.name: Transparent Noun
semType.definition: Transparent noun.

semType.name: Body_part
semType.definition: Type for all body parts of humans and animals.

semType.name: Positive_judgment
semType.definition: This semantic type is used to mark words in the Judgment frame and related frames (like Punishments_and_rewards) as involving a positive judgment by a Cognizer, i.e. a Cognizer respecting or approving to actions of an Evaluee. (See Negative_judgment.)

semType.name: Negative_judgment
semType.definition: This type is used to mark lexical units involving a negative judgment (on the part of the Judge) in frames related to Judgment, such as Punishment. It is also used to denote the opinion of the speaker associated with words in several other frames (such as Frugality and Appearance), including a more heterogeneous variety of words having the prefixes 'mis-', 'under-', and 'over-'. It is also used of words which indicate undesirable effects, e.g. warp, in frames such as Reshaping.

semType.name: Container
semType.definition: Marks FEs extending over constituents whose denotatum is a container.

semType.name: Non-Lexical Frame
semType.definition: Used to describe frames that don't have corresponding lexical items in English.

semType.name: Region
semType.definition: Labels LU's that designate solid ground defined in terms of the shape of a border with water. Equivalent to WN Geological formation, which, however, is not a supertype of Body of Water.

semType.name: Achievement
semType.definition: Aspectual type for predicators which describe "achievements"; e.g. Gloria recognized the boy (in an instant) *for an hour. (One kind of "telic", the other is "accomplishment")

semType.name: Accomplishment
semType.definition: Aspectual type for predicators that describe "accomplishments", which include both activities and their culmination e.g. They climbed the mountain (in two days). N.B. _They climbed the mountain for two days_ describes an activity, not an accomplishment-- there is no implication that they reached the top.

semType.name: Interrogative
semType.definition: This semantic type signals that the marked LU is dedicated for use in questions. The FE that is to be questioned is underdetermined by this semantic type, but is inferrable as the sole Core FE in the frame of the LU (e.g., Person in the People frame for the LU People.who.n) or the most focal (non-topical) FE in a frame with multiple Core FEs (e.g., Profiled_region in the Locative_relation frame for where.adv).

semType.name: Non-perspectivalized_frame
semType.definition: This semantic type marks frames that do not impose a perspective on the situation portrayed by the frame. An example is the Commerce frame, in which a Lexical Unit like commerce.n denotes an interaction between participants (Buyer, Seller, Money, and Goods) but profiles none of them. An important consequence of the lack of perspective is that the opposition of core, periperal, and extrathematic frame elements is not relevant.

semType.name: Location
semType.definition: WN synset: location

semType.name: Content
semType.definition: WN synset: content, cognitive content, mental object

semType.name: Message
semType.definition: WN synset: message, content, subject matter, substance

semType.name: Social relation
semType.definition: WN synset: social relation

semType.name: Organization
semType.definition: WN synset: organization, organisation.

semType.name: Quantity
semType.definition: WN synset: measure, quantity, amount, quantum

semType.name: Shape
semType.definition: WN synset: shape, form

semType.name: Artifact
semType.definition: WN synset: artifact, artefact

semType.name: Structure
semType.definition: WN synset: structure, construction

semType.name: Material
semType.definition: WN synset: material, stuff

semType.name: Animate_being
semType.definition: WN synset: animal, animate being, beast, brute, creature, fauna

semType.name: Living_thing
semType.definition: WN synset: organism, being, living thing

semType.name: Physical_object
semType.definition: WN synset: object, physical object

semType.name: Human_act
semType.definition: WN synset (top): act, human action, human activity

semType.name: Physical_entity
semType.definition: WN synset (top): entity

semType.name: Event
semType.definition: WN synset (top): event

semType.name: Group
semType.definition: WN synset (top): group, grouping

semType.name: State
semType.definition: WN synset (top): state

semType.name: Human
semType.definition: WN synset: person, individual, someone, somebody, mortal, human, soul

semType.name: Front_back
semType.definition: Direction is established as not Vertical and along the current or normal axis of motion, interaction, or viewing of the Landmark.

semType.name: Vertical
semType.definition: Direction is established as along the axis of current or usual gravity.

semType.name: Cardinal
semType.definition: Direction is established as not Vertical and with reference to magnetic North, sunrise/sunset, or other universally available orientation methods.

semType.name: Leftish
semType.definition: Direction is established as to the left with respect to the Landmark, either based on viewpoint or based on properties of the Landmark; equivalently, towards the vector cross-product of On_top and Front.

semType.name: Rightish
semType.definition: Direction is established as to the right with respect to the Landmark, either based on viewpoint or based on properties of the Landmark; equivalently, towards the vector cross-product of Underneath and Front.

semType.name: Tendency_grading_LU
semType.definition: This semantic type marks adjectives generally having the meaning "able to be Verb-ed" (thus implicitly evoking the Capability frame). With these adjectives, the verbal notion is incorporated in the meaning of the adjective. (In most cases, this is reflected in the morphological composition of the adjective, which combines a verb stem with the affix -able/-ible.) These adjectives allow Degree modification, which may not be realized with other lexical units in the frame.

semType.name: Sensory_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type (and its children) mark lexical units that refer to sense modalities.

semType.name: Auditory_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexical units that refer to auditory sensation.

semType.name: Visual_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexlical units that refer to visual perception.

semType.name: Olfactory_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexlical units that refer to olfactory perception.

semType.name: Tactile_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexlical units that refer to tactile sensation.

semType.name: Gustatory_modality
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexlical units that refer to gustatory perception.

semType.name: End_of_scale
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexical units that indicate that a property is maximal or minimal.

semType.name: Negative
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexical units as referring to the marked end of a scale.

semType.name: Agentive_noun
semType.definition: A sentient being that acts volitionally to perform an activity. <ex></ex> Use of this semantic type indicates that a target participates in a nominalization construction with frame elements appropriate to entities (cf. People frame), which can appear in addition to frame elements approporiate to the event.

semType.name: Support
semType.definition: This semantic type marks lexical units which can be used in a frame only when introduced by a frame evoking element, i.e., in cases when it functions as a support. Note that such lexical units are not intended to be subcorporated and annotated outside of the context of the lexical units that introduce them.

semType.name: Front
semType.definition: In the direction of motion, conventional motion, or in the direction of perception or manipulation, or in the direction of access (e.g. "in front of")

semType.name: Back
semType.definition: Opposite of the direction of motion, or opposite the direction of perception or access (e.g. "behind")

semType.name: Lateral
semType.definition: approximately 90 degrees from top/bottom or front/back (e.g. "beside")

semType.name: Near_absolute_orientation
semType.definition: LUs with such a type normally specify the orientation of an associated Image Schema with reference to an absolute direction, but may contextually allow use of the prototypical orientation of the Landmark.

semType.name: On_top
semType.definition: Usually refers to the direction currently against gravity, occasionally refers to the direction that normally points against gravity from a landmark (e.g. "on top of")

semType.name: Underneath
semType.definition: Usually refers to the current direction of gravity, occasionally refers to the direction gravity normally points from a landmark (e.g. "underneath")

semType.name: Landmark_based_orientation
semType.definition: LUs with such a type normally orient an associated Image Schema relative to an axis provided by the Ground.

semType.name: Top
semType.definition: The axis of the associated Image Schema points along the axis of the Landmark that is normally oriented against gravity; in cases where there is no basis for inherently differentiating sides or there is no norm of orientation, this defaults to simply the direction against gravity. (e.g. "the top of")

semType.name: Bottom
semType.definition: The axis of the associated Image Schema points along the axis of the Landmark that is normally oriented in the direction of gravity; in cases where there is no basis for inherently differentiating sides or there is no norm of orientation, this defaults to simply the direction of gravity. (e.g. "the bottom of")

semType.name: Landmark_front
semType.definition: Pointing in the normal direction of action or access; defaults to current direction of motion or, rarely, the direction from the part of the Landmark that is facing the Viewpoint (e.g. "(at) the front of")

semType.name: Landmark_back
semType.definition: Pointing against the normal direction of action or access; defaults to the opposite direction from current motion or, rarely, the direction from the part of the Landmark that is facing away from the Viewpoint (e.g. "(at) the back of")

semType.name: Landmark_left
semType.definition: To the left relative to the landmark's own orientation (e.g. "to X's left"); formally, towards the vector cross-product of Top and Landmark_front

semType.name: Landmark_right
semType.definition: To the right relative to the landmark's own orientation (e.g. "to X's right"); formally, towards the vector cross-product of Bottom and Landmark_front

semType.name: Absolute_direction_orientation
semType.definition: Direction is established with reference to gravity and the terrestrial grid.

semType.name: North
semType.definition: Pointing towards magnetic north or true (earth-axis) north (e.g. "north")

semType.name: South
semType.definition: Pointing in the opposite direction from magnetic north or true (earth-axis) north (e.g. "south")

semType.name: East
semType.definition: Pointing towards the local sunrise (e.g. "east"); formally, towards the vector cross-product of Downward and North.

semType.name: West
semType.definition: Pointing towards the local sunset (e.g. "west"); formally, towards the vector cross-product of Upward and North.

semType.name: Upward
semType.definition: Against the direction of gravity; directly away from the center of the planet (e.g. "above")

semType.name: Downward
semType.definition: In the direction of gravity; directly towards the center of the planet (e.g. "below")

semType.name: Not_up_or_down
semType.definition: In a horizontal direction (e.g. "around", "beside").

semType.name: Motion_based_orientation
semType.definition: Direction is established with reference to the motion of a Landmark; frequently, motion is generalized to the overall motion expected in the situation, as, for example, when people in a line are largely motionless moment by moment, but there is an expected direction of motion.

semType.name: Ahead
semType.definition: In the direction of motion (e.g. "ahead of")

semType.name: After
semType.definition: In a direction opposite the direction of motion (e.g. "behind the plane", "in the wake of")

semType.name: Viewpoint_based_orientation
semType.definition: Direction for these LUs is established by the conventional orientation of a (fictive or actual) Viewer. In English, this is relevant only for Viewpoint based "left of" and "right of".

semType.name: Viewpoint_leftward
semType.definition: In the direction of the Viewer's left from the Landmark (e.g. "to the left of")

semType.name: Viewpoint_rightward
semType.definition: In the direction of the Viewer's right from the Landmark (e.g. "to the right of")

semType.name: Time
semType.definition: Marks FEs whose fillers denote points in time.

semType.name: Duration
semType.definition: Marks FEs which have time-periods as fillers.

semType.name: Source
semType.definition: Marks FEs whose fillers depict a location as formerly occupied before motion.

semType.name: Path
semType.definition: Marks FEs whose fillers denote a location along the path of motion.

semType.name: Goal
semType.definition: Marks FEs whose fillers denote a location that is the destination of motion.

semType.name: Attribute
semType.definition: Ontological type from which more specific attributes such as Shape and Quantity inherit.

semType.name: Degree
semType.definition: Type for expressions of degree, such as _very_, _completely_, _somewhat_ and _partially_.

semType.name: Manner
semType.definition: Type for expressions of the manner of an event or action: _suddenly_, _gradually_, _grudgingly_

semType.name: Relation
semType.definition: Type for relations in general, inherited by more specific relation types.

semType.name: Point
semType.definition: Type for locations expressed as points: _at the top of the Empire State Building_, _a peak of $36/share_.

semType.name: Line
semType.definition: Type for locations viewed as lines: _on West Main St._, _the equator_

semType.name: State_of_affairs
semType.definition: Type for states of affairs broadly defined, including states, events and the content of messages: _her happiness_, _your graduation_, _the Big Bang_

semType.name: Ontological_type
semType.definition: Supertype for FN semantic types on FEs, corresponding roughly to nodes in other ontologies.

semType.name: Framal_type
semType.definition: Supertype for types on frames; FrameNet-specific. Subtypes of this frame are used to mark meta-information on frames.

semType.name: Lexical_type
semType.definition: Supertype for types on LUs or words

semType.name: Intentional_act
semType.definition: Type for intentional actions; i.e. actions performed by sentient beings in furtherance of their own intentions.

semType.name: Locative_relation
semType.definition: Type for relations between events and locations.

semType.name: Affect_describing
semType.definition: Lexical units associated with positive or negative affect with regard to some phenomenon.

semType.name: LU_with_FE_specified
semType.definition: Type for LUs which specify features on some of their FEs that are not simply cases of denotation or incorporation.

semType.name: Value_for_degree
semType.definition: Supertype for types having to do with the degree expressed by certain LUs.

semType.name: Biframal_LU
semType.definition: Type for LUs that are closely associated with the frame in which they appear but actually denote one of the FEs in the frame or denote a specified frame and take the current Frame itself as an FE.

semType.name: Bound_LU
semType.definition:
This ST is used for LUs of a frame that cannot be used (for interpretation or generation) unless they co-occur with the right other words as governors or dependents. (The limiting case, where a precise group of words must all co-occur in order to evoke a frame, is handled in FrameNet by the use of multi-word lexical units.) The Support subtype of bound lexical unit is exemplified by give with a causal meaning:
Receiving the notification so late almost gave me a heart attack.
Give.v in the Causation frame is usable with a large number of dependents denoting the Effect, but not all:
Releasing these old files nearly gave a disaster.
The Bound_dependent_LU type is used for LUs like pickle.n in the Predicament frame, which occurs virtually only with the supports in and out of.

semType.name: Bound_dependent_LU
semType.definition: This ST marks LUs that require one of a list of particular supports or governors in order to have the meaning of the frame.

semType.name: Guest_LU
semType.definition:
This type is applied to LUs which are only tangentially used in the current frame, and whose interpretation is still largely dependent on their membership in some other frame, e.g. grin used in the Statement frame:
"You'll never catch up," she grinned.
Such LUs are only meant to be used for full-text annotation.

semType.name: Participating_entity
semType.definition:
This type marks LUs which denote a non-active participant of the current frame, either an entity in the relationship described in the frame, or (more commonly) an entity affected by the action of the frame. Such LUs must incorporate a frame-element of the frame.
An example is the noun victim in the Crime frame, or the noun possession_((entity)).n in the Possession frame.

semType.name: Temperature
semType.definition: An attribute of physical objects, technically defined in terms of degree of molecular motion, but effectively grounded in bodily sensations of warmth or cold.

semType.name: Speed
semType.definition: Distance traveled divided by time.

semType.name: End_state_LU
semType.definition:
This semantic type indicates that the labeled lexical unit denotes the end-state of a causative process denoted by the frame. The Agent, Cause, Time, and Purpose (if any) of the process are completely deprofiled and unexpressible. These lexical units are generally derived as past-participles (in form) from verbs in the same frame.
Exx: chilled.a, heated.a in *Cause_change_of_temperature, designed.a in Invention, persuaded.a in Suasion

semType.name: Axis_specified
semType.definition: LUs with this type have a specified strategy for orienting an associated image schema.

semType.name: Flexible_orientation
semType.definition: LUs with such a type flexibly, depending on context, establish orientation of their associated Image Schema via motion of a Theme, potential motion of a Theme, sensory apparatus of a Theme, manipulatory apparatus of a Theme, or the viewpoint of the observer
